Award.AwardTitle: What Determines Whether the Deep Continental Crust Flows?
Award.AbstractNarration: Understanding why and how the deep continental crust flows at high temperature and pressure is central to understanding a broad range of geologic processes. There is however, uncertainty about how to quantify the influence of many factorsÂ¬-including rock composition, temperature, grain size, strain, fluid activity, and/or degree of melting. This research uses the ages and compositions of the minerals titanite, rutile and zircon to test which factors permitted or inhibited the flow of continental crust at high pressure and temperature in a well-understood part of Norway. The impact of this research should be considerable and broad because of the archetypal nature of the Norwegian terrane. Although this proposal is targeted toward understanding why the deep continental crust flows, it will also help pinpoint why mineral reactions in Earth are sometimes very slow. Answers to these questions address why Earth?s tectonic plates move, why earthquakes occur, how long mountain ranges exist, and the composition of Earth's crust. This project provides training and research for U.S. students and brings together scientists and students from the U.S., Norway, and France, providing cross-cultural experiences that ensure that the collaborative impact of this project will be long lasting. The laboratory approach in this project is relatively new and its continued development will enable further expansion into other fields, such as biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied the deformation and flow processes that occur deep within Earth, specifically to understand why some rocks at high temperature undergo strong large scale deformation, whereas others do not. We made several useful discoveries using a combination of field measurements of rock deformation and crystallization, laboratory measurements of mineral compositions and radiometric dates, and calculations of rock physical and chemical properties: 1) U-Pb dating of titanium silicate shows that a 100 x 200 km region of Norway that reached temperatures in Earth as high as 800 °C contains multi kilometer scale pockets that did not deform. The reason for this is a combination of low amounts of free H2O and a large grain size. 2) Monazite, a mineral made mostly of cerium phosphate that contains small amounts of thorium, shows clearly that dry, coarse grained rocks are slow to transform to high pressure minerals and slow to deform compared to H2O bearing finer grained rocks. This funding supported two graduate students, leading to the completion of a MS and continuing work by a PhD student. Undergraduate students participated in the research. Support of UCSB laboratory facilities allowed local college and K-12 students to visit and obtain an appreciation for what scientists do and allowed technology transfer to the corporations that built components of our facility.
